speech.para: The claim the minister has just given to us comes from the Centre for International Economics, hardly a group with environmental expertise. In fact, it is an insult to this committee, to this parliament and to this country that a former minister for the environment in this government should say that their dismissal of environmental effects—from their point of inexpertise—should be seen as a national environmental impact statement, a national environmental effects statement, about the potential impact of this treaty. I get back to the press release, which states:

quote.para: ACF Campaigns Director John Connor said Environment Minister Ian Campbell was wrong to claim that an environmental impact assessment had been conducted—

speech.para: he ought to have informed Minister Hill before tonight about that, but the message did not go through—

quote.para: to determine whether the environment would be adversely affected by the US Australia FTA.

“The Centre for International Economics report, with a small environmental chapter, cannot be claimed to represent an environmental assessment of the agreement. The report itself acknowledges this ...

speech.para: The minister might want to hear this. Mr Connor said the CIE report review:

quote.para: ... does not attempt to provide a full scale quantitative assessment of the consequences of the Agreement on the environment.

speech.para: So the minister's proposition is exploded at the outset. ACF campaigns director John Connor went on to say:

quote.para: “The CIE report was inadequate in terms of public input and final content. For example it failed to look at impacts of the agreement on water consumption, land disturbance and energy use. It cannot be passed off as meeting the FTA's requirement for a review of the environmental effects of the FTA at the first meeting of the Joint Committee—

speech.para: and Mr Connor there refers to the section that I have been referring to. He goes on to say:

quote.para: “There is little doubt that the US/Australia FTA will have dramatic implications for Australia's law-making processes, and force governments to think twice before introducing important environmental and public health regulations.

“Government initiatives around water, waste management, energy and the management of our national parks will ... be scrutinised and subjected to special tests designed to show the least burdensome approach for US investors.

speech.para: The minister nods at that. The press release continues:

quote.para: “The NSW, Victorian and ACT Governments have all expressed their concern that any new environment protection initiatives imposed after the FTA has come into effect could result in massive compensation payouts to US companies.”
Earlier this week six large ... environment groups—

speech.para: including the Sierra Club—

quote.para: said the agreement in its current form threatened to undermine environmental protection in both countries.

“There is an urgent need for new trade legislation that will grant Parliament a greater role and say in the process and ensure that the environmental and social impacts of future trade agreements are assessed prior to signing and implementation,” said Mr Connor.

speech.para: I will summarise this as far as we have got it. I asked the minister about the review of the environmental effects and the environmental assessment and he said he did not know. I then quoted from article 21.1(7), which says that there must be one before the first meeting of the joint committee so it can be presented to the first meeting. He said, `That has been done through the Centre for International Economics,' but the Centre for International Economics itself says that the review does not attempt to provide a full-scale quantitative assessment of the environmental effects. So it is not that at all.

So what we are left with here is a minister who does not know and presumably does not care. The government has not fulfilled the obligation under the terms of the treaty. There has been no opportunity for the public to provide its views on the environmental effects. We are moving to have this legislation rushed through the parliament now because there is an election coming and it will be good for the CVs of the big parties. A basic requirement about the national impact on the environment in this country is not understood by the government. It does not know what is in its own treaty; it does not know what is in the agreement it signed—far from meeting the requirements of it.

The questions are: how is the government going to fulfil the requirement of the agreement that there be an environmental effects statement before the first meeting of this all-powerful joint committee which oversees the whole implementation of the treaty? If you cannot get the first meeting passed, the whole system will break down. If the government cannot fulfil the first obligation, what about the rest? Is this a boys club meeting in which this joint committee in secret says: `Oh, well, we'll scrub that'? It is not going to worry the Australian government if there is an impact on the environment—`Look at our record,' they will say; `Why? We won't bother. The United States is doing a full environmental impact assessment, but that is for them over there.' As Senator Hill says, they have a different system.

We do not have to do an environmental impact assessment under our law, which is sidelined by this treaty, and the minister says, `I don't know. I think some organisation—the CIE—has done it.' But the CIE say themselves that they have not fulfilled that obligation. The question goes again to the minister: when will this requirement for an environmental effects review be done? When will the opportunity for the public to provide views on those effects be enabled? How is this joint committee going to move on if that prior requirement for its first meeting has not been fulfilled?

talk.start.para: —Senator Brown puts a lot of words into my mouth. He tends to prefer that to listening to answers. What I tried to explain to him is that, under our environmental law, it is the environmental actions themselves that are judged. When they are of national environmental significance, they may well trigger the Commonwealth environment protection and biodiversity conservation legislation. The system is different to the United States system. When Senator Brown says that the agreement may have an effect on energy, waste, land clearing or water, the answer is that it is not the agreement itself that has that effect; it is actions that are unrelated to the agreement.

speech.para: Senator Brown's argument is that any attempt to encourage exploitation of natural resources per se has environmental consequences that must be judged. We say that the actions that are taken—if actions are taken to expand, for example, Australia's agricultural production through land clearing—might in themselves trigger the Commonwealth legislation, but not a free trade agreement as such. The free trade agreement does not directly lead to the consequence that Senator Brown is concerned about at all. Advice was sought, and the advice was that the agreement does not in itself trigger the Commonwealth legislation, which does not surprise me. That is what I have been trying to tell Senator Brown. Whether there are other actions in the future that do trigger it will be something that we will have to see. And whether those actions are related to the agreement is also something that will have to be assessed.

In relation to this agreement, it is not 21.7 but 21.1(7), and it is true that the parties will report to the joint committee. But the report of Australia would be in terms of the Australian law, which I have just outlined, because the agreement provides the obligation on each state to comply with its own environmental law. So that is what the report will cover—

talk.start.para: —Where does it say that?
—It is in the chapter on environment. The primary obligation is for each state to comply with their environmental law. It is in 19.2(1), which states:

quote.para: (a) A Party shall not fail to effectively enforce its environmental laws ...

speech.para: So one can go on. That is the primary obligation under chapter 19 of the agreement. We respect each other's environmental laws and we accept an obligation to comply with our own environmental laws and, provided that we are complying with our own environmental laws, we meet our commitment to the other party.

Senator Brown might not like it being done that way; he may well feel that we have got to account further than that to the United States. It would not surprise me if he says that, because already tonight he has said he has a preference for the US system of government when it comes to treaties. He says he has a preference for US environmental law. He seems to have a preference for US environmental assessments. But it is my view that our system works and, if I might be so bold, I actually think our system works better than that of the United States when it comes to environmental protection.

talk.start.para: —I also want to say a few things about this issue because, as a member of the select committee that looked at this issue—as well as having been a member of the committee that looked at Advancing the national interest—I think it is disingenuous on the part of the minister to take a very narrow approach to looking at the question of an environmental analysis. The minister might recall that, back in March by way of a question here in the chamber, I indicated that—given that the CIE analysis was only going to deal with the economic bottom line, and given that there was a legal requirement through the US trade commission for the US to undertake an environmental impact assessment, which I have no difficulties with—I thought it was incumbent on the government to instruct CIE to undertake that analysis, most of all because that is where I think the free trade agreement falls down, particularly in terms of environmental policy.

speech.para: The minister might say that it is a question of the government retaining the right to deal with environmental regulation in the future. That is in respect of a very narrow issue in relation to how the EPBC Act itself might work. Given that there has been very little, if any, analysis done on the environment, the JSCOT recommended that there should be legislation to deal with an environmental impact and to also look at the provision of this in the legislation. We do not seem to have a response from the government about that. If you take a broad approach to environmental impact assessment, I think it also goes to the question of looking at our ability to protect our island nation, particularly in terms of the imported diseases that may or may not come as a result of trade. The government is not giving any satisfactory response—or any answer—to that question, and that has not been analysed in any great detail as a result of all of the inquiries that have been conducted. In the context of environmental health policy, it perhaps also goes to the question of genetically modified products, particularly in terms of the labelling laws. The minister might want to answer the question about how the EPBC Act is going to deal with issues of that sort.

It is disingenuous to suggest that we are only talking about issues of land clearing here; the impact is much wider than that. It goes to a range of industry assistance programs, tax benefits and subsidies and how they might change or be interfered with. Where they are being provided to industry in this country, I agree that the EPBC Act might apply in those circumstances, but will structural arrangements as far as tax benefits, subsidies and the like have an impact—positive or negative—on the environment?

These are pertinent questions that the minister needs to answer. That is why back in March we asked for some sort of guarantee from the government that they would instruct CIE to undertake an analysis of environmental, social and cultural outcomes. If I recall correctly, the minister's response was that some of these things cannot be quantified. If they cannot be quantified, how is the United States managing to do that? It is really fobbing off the reality that the analysis of the free trade agreement looked only at the economic bottom line and outcomes—without regard for the environment and social and cultural policy.

Again I ask the minister to respond to the JSCOT recommendation about reviewing the environmental impact of the free trade agreement and legislating for this to happen for all future free trade agreements. It was wise on their part to suggest that. Is the government happy to accept that recommendation? When can we expect to see the results of a review being done and tabled in parliament? Is the minister proposing to table that assessment during the course of this debate?

JSCOT also went on to recommend that there be provision within this package of enabling legislation to ensure that an environmental impact assessment is undertaken with all future FTAs. I do not see any mention of that and wonder whether the minister might respond to that question as well. We need to look more broadly at the question of what an environmental analysis is. It is not just about land clearing; it is also about other issues that go to how our industries operate and to sustainability goals being met. Quite frankly, all the reports are deficient in that respect—most of all because the government has not given the instruction to its consultants, as was requested by the Senate on that occasion. The Senate passed a motion calling on the government to do that, and I believe that it has failed—it did not instruct CIE to go away and look at that question.

In the context of the debate on this issue, it is legitimate to ask why these things are being overlooked. If we are to make a proper assessment of what is in this agreement for Australia, we must also look at environmental, social and cultural outcomes. Frankly, the government has been negligent in its responsibilities.

talk.start.para: —There is an ongoing debate as to how useful environmental assessments of free trade agreements are. I know the Europeans see value in them, and in the last few years there has been a trend towards them in the United States, but from the assessments I have read they are of marginal value because it is not the agreement in itself that leads to the threatening actions.

speech.para: Australia is as committed to protecting its environmental values as it is to protecting its quarantine system and its PBS. There were a lot of fundamentals that we were not prepared to put at risk in the negotiation of this agreement. This agreement does not override Australia's environmental laws, and I am not just talking about Commonwealth law—you cannot just look at Commonwealth law; you have to look at the different tiers of environmental protection in Australia. The primary responsibility for natural resource management still lies with the states.

This agreement is not going to threaten any of those environmental values. Whether environmental values are adequately preserved depends on the adequacy of our domestic legislation and its enforcement. That is an issue for this parliament, and we have legislation at the national level to assist us. Environmental protection is also an issue for the state parliaments in relation to their areas of responsibility. As I said, as far as the Commonwealth is concerned, if there are actions in the future that threaten matters of national environmental significance, Commonwealth legislation may be triggered and action can be taken to protect those values. Despite what Senator Ridgeway said, I was not just talking about land clearing; I mentioned water, energy and other issues.

It is legitimate for him to talk about genetically modified products. We have a process in Australia to evaluate the consequences of those actions, and that is being implemented. The release of genetically modified organisms has to be pursuant to the Commonwealth regulatory structure. That is the protection that this parliament has put in place, and it will exist whether or not a free trade agreement is entered into with the United States.

How to best protect Australia's environmental values is always worth debating, but I would respectfully suggest that it is not so relevant to tonight's debate. If Senator Ridgeway wants to come back later and argue for changes to Commonwealth environmental legislation on matters of national environmental significance, he can do so. I know it is the position of the Australian Democrats that other areas should be triggered by that legislation and that the list should be expanded. That is a legitimate debate to have, but it is for Australia to determine domestically and, if Australia determines that it wishes to do so, it is not relevant to the United States under this agreement. We will protect and conserve our environment. We will not put it at risk by this agreement. I would hope that we will continue to produce sustainably, but that is in the hands of Australians. It is not something that the United States is going to cause us to revisit. Obviously it is easy to argue either way. Clearly there are some states that see value in environmental assessments of framework agreements of this type; however, I think a more effective form of assessment is one that focuses on a specific proposed action, because then you can get a clearer evaluation of whether that specific proposed action is a threat. That is the system that we have developed in this country, and I think it is working quite effectively.

talk.start.para: —I rise to commence One Nation's contribution to the committee stage of the US Free Trade Agreement Implementation Bill 2004. Earlier on we heard Senator Hill calling people back to the bill. That is exactly what I would like to do, and I would like to ask Senator Hill some questions about the bill. Before doing that, though, the chamber needs to look at the scope of the bill that is before it. It is the US Free Trade Agreement Implementation Bill 2004. What does it implement? What does it change? Here is the list. It changes the Customs Act 1901, the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemical Code Act 1994, the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation Act 1980, the Life Insurance Act 1995, the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975, the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act 1997, the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989, the Patents Act 1990, the Copyright Act 1968 and the Telecommunications Act 1997. The title of the bill is rather innocuous but it has the effect of altering 10 of the major pieces of legislation under which corporations operate in this country, under which states carry out their activities and under which each and every one of us conducts our lives. The bill has a simple title but it has very complex outcomes.

speech.para: Let us look briefly at the first act that we will alter, the Customs Act 1901. In schedule 1 of the US Free Trade Agreement Implementation Bill, under `Customs amendments', the first thing we find is that we are altering definitions in the Customs Act. Under the subheading of `definitions', section 153YA `Interpretations'—paragraph 1, line 10, page 6—says:

quote.para: Australian originating goods means goods that are Australian originating goods under a law of the US that implements the Agreement.

speech.para: Stop and think about the wording of that definition. Have a look at the adjectives in it. What is the operating function of that change? I will read it again:

quote.para: Australian originating goods means goods that are Australian originating goods under a law of the US that implements the Agreement.

speech.para: What the hell have the Yanks got to do with defining what `Australian originating goods' means? That is what the definition says. It does not say that it means goods that are originating goods under an Australian act; it says `under a law of the US'. On page 7, `indirect materials' are described as:

quote.para: (a) goods used in the production, testing or inspection of other goods, but that are not physically incorporated in the other goods; or
(b) goods used in the operation or maintenance of buildings or equipment associated with the production of other goods; including:
(g) Catalysts and solvents.

speech.para: What effect will the change in that definition have on manufacturers in Australia? Again on page 7, at line 24 it states:

quote.para: originating materials means:
(a) goods that are used in the production of other goods and that are US originating goods; or
(b) goods that are used in the production of other goods and that are Australian originating goods;

speech.para: We have a balance in that definition. It goes on to say `or (c) indirect materials'. Unless my comprehension of the English language is somewhat lacking—and I do not believe it is—I find the following example even more confusing. It says:

quote.para: ... This example illustrates goods produced from originating materials
and non-originating materials.

speech.para: Simple—there are two types of materials in the goods—

quote.para: Pork sausages are produced in the US from US cereals, Hungarian frozen pork meat and Brazilian spices.
The US cereals are originating materials since they are goods used in the production of other goods—

speech.para: in other words, the sausages—

quote.para: and they are US originating goods under Subdivision B.

speech.para: But this example does not help us, because it does not explain in any way what happens to the Hungarian frozen pork meat and the Brazilian spices. Because they are part of a product that has originating material in it from the US, do they all of a sudden become originating materials of the US for the purpose of this agreement? Unless I am totally missing the reason and the concept of that example, whoever wrote it has not defined it clearly and has left us in a worse state than we were in before we read it. When I consider that this legislation will be used to define disputes within Australia's territorial borders—and in all probability those disputes will end up in a court of law—I have some grave concerns about either the mischief or the difficulty that people will have in relation to that example.
Moving to page 8 of the definitions, line 4 refers to `produce'. It states:

quote.para: produce means grow, raise, mine, harvest, fish, trap, hunt ...

speech.para: I wonder how many in our mining industry would have any concept of the definition that `mining' is now being carried in. Let us go back. What section are we looking at? It is customs amendments. Why have we got a mined product? How can you have something that is mined and, under a law of Australia, subject to a customs amendment? My understanding is that a customs issue relates to incoming product—unless our mining products are now to be exposed to some customs regulation in the exporting stage.
Line 13 on page 9 refers to regulations. This is where the apoplexy really sets in.
Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I hear a chuckle from the government side. Line 14 through to 16 states:

quote.para: For the purposes of this Division, the regulations may apply, adopt or incorporate any matter contained in any instrument or other writing as in force or existing from time to time.

speech.para: I think this is one issue that we will have to spend some time on with the minister. If `writing' refers—as it does in the Acts Interpretation Act at 15AB—to anything printed by the government printer, then I accept that as being reasonable. If it refers to anything else and is open to anything greater than that then I have grave concerns, because it is through regulations that our departments administer these types of changes. Remember, we are altering the Customs Act 1901. These words will have effect in relation to that act.
So, just to reiterate for the minister, the concern I have is that regulations may, to use the government's own wording:

quote.para: ... apply, adopt or incorporate any matter contained in any instrument ...

speech.para: We do not have a definition of `instrument'. What type of instrument are we talking about? Is it an instrument from the Senate, is it an instrument from the House of Representatives or is it an instrument from a judicial proceeding? It then goes on to say:

quote.para: ... or other writing as in force or existing from time to time.

speech.para: I have no problems with `from time to time', but I believe that that wording is so open as to cause great concern to anybody who is required, through their business, to work through the Customs Act. Through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, I look forward to the minister's explanation.

talk.start.para: —I thought we were debating the Greens' first amendment, but, nevertheless, I will have a go at answering Senator Harris's questions because I am sure that sometime during the debate they will have to be dealt with. We might as well start with them now. In relation to the first issue that he raised—which was: why do you apply the US law in determining whether it is an originating product?—we are talking about products originating in Australia going into the United States. The issue is whether we get the benefit of the preferred tariff. To get the benefit, it obviously would have to be an originating product under their law and vice versa—if it was a product coming into Australia then it would have to be an originating product under our law. I do not see any particular concern in that. That is the way in which we get our advantage under this agreement.

speech.para: In relation to the definitions of originating materials, obviously you have to have definitions. If benefits flow to originating materials then you have to deal with that under the legislation, and we seek to do that. We also address the issue of products that are partly comprised of originating material and partly comprised of non-originating material. I think the bill before the chamber this evening is quite helpful in its examples. It gives an example of goods that are produced from originating materials and non-originating materials. The examples are those that were given by Senator Harris. I have to say that that seems reasonably clear to me.

Senator Harris asked why produce includes the product of mines. It is because we get benefits under the legislation in the export of our products, including minerals, into the United States. So the broader that definition, the better off we are. Again, I do not see any problem in that—it is a benefit to us. Senator Harris referred to the provision which states:

quote.para: ... For the purposes of this Division, the regulations may apply, adopt or incorporate any matter contained in any instrument or other writing as in force or existing from time to time.

speech.para: That provides that the regulations may, if such a decision is taken, do just that. On the face of it, that does not seem to me to be extraordinary either. It gives a capacity for flexibility in relation to the regulations to pick up other existing instruments, which may well be to our advantage again.

I accept that if you are going to go into the fine details of the customs legislation, one will find that it is a very complex environment. I do not think there is any way of avoiding that. Part of this implementing bill before the chamber is to reduce the obstacles to Australia under the customs regime of the United States—in other words, to be able to provide a better opportunity for Australia to be able to export these products competitively into the United States. That is what this is about. We on this side of the chamber obviously believe that more open access to the United States market is potentially of great benefit to Australian producers; and therefore the Australian economy and all Australians. If improved access is going to be given then it has to be subject to rules and definitions. I do not think there is any way to avoid that. The fact that the rules and definitions are complex is, I am afraid, also just part of contemporary legal life—such that, on occasions, we even have to seek advice from others on issues of interpretation.

talk.start.para: —I would like to continue briefly on that point. I have a question for Senator Hill that relates particularly to the regulations. As you read out, for the purposes of this division the regulations may apply, adopt or incorporate matters. If they were to incorporate writings, then those writings would actually become part of the regulation. Under the wording as I see it written here, it would be possible for a regulation to adopt a writing without physically incorporating it within the regulation. If that is the case, I see that as being of concern. If the regulation in adopting writings as enforced is required to physically incorporate them in the regulation, that would give everybody in this chamber the ability to peruse them and make a decision on whether they ought to become part of a disallowance motion. The question I am asking very clearly is whether, under the structure of the wording, it is possible for a regulation to actually adopt writings without incorporating them as part of the regulation.

—Speaking on a general basis, it would have to make specific reference to the relevant writing and adopt it in a way that is clear. It does not mean that you have to necessarily transcribe the other writing into the new regulation, but it has to be referred to explicitly; you have to have clarity in the law. I am seeking further expert advice, but I think all this provision is doing is making it clear that the regulations may apply or adopt or incorporate such other matters. There would have to be, in my view, specific action for that to occur.
—In order to help the committee, I have previously moved amendment (1) on sheet 4351 but I now seek leave to move amendment (1) on sheet 4366 and ask that they be dealt with together.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move Australian Greens amendment (1) on sheet 4366:

quote.para: (1) Page 4 (after line 11), after clause 3, add:

(1) The Joint Committee and each committee and working group established under the agreement must, on or before each 30 June and 31 December occurring after the agreement enters into force, provide to the minister a report on:

speech.para: (a) membership and attendance at meetings;
(b) numbers of meetings;
(c) issues considered and decisions and recommendations made at meetings;
(d) any other activities.

quote.para: (2) The minister must cause each report provided under subsection (2) to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 5 days after the report is provided to the minister.

(3) For the purposes of subsection (3), if a House does not meet within 5 days after a report is provided, the minister must present the report to the Presiding Officer of that House or to a person authorised to perform the duties of that Presiding Officer.
(4) An instrument that gives effect to, or interprets, any provision of the agreement is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

speech.para: I have moved amendment (1) on both those sheets, because the definition in amendment (1) on sheet 4351 simply says that the agreement means that the US-Australia free trade agreement applies to the substantive amendment on sheet 4366. This is about parliamentary scrutiny and the reporting of the agreement back to parliament. This is an enormously important amendment for the Greens and I thank the committee for agreeing to that. I want to come back to the environmental component—you know, Senator Harris, that we will keep coming back to the environmental issue until it is cleared, which may be the best way for me to put that.

The minister incorrectly said, `The laws of Australia will look after the environment and that, really, the study by the Centre for International Economics was to look at the impact on the laws and that the two things do not cross over'. That is wrong on both counts. The Centre for International Economics makes that clear. If you look at its seven-page contribution on the environment you will see that it did a best guess effort at a 0.01 per cent increase in greenhouse gases in Australia as a result of the agreement—that is, it did look at the environmental impact of the agreement per se and it did take into account methane emissions from cattle, for example, if Australia has increased beef production as a result of the agreement, and it offset that by saying that it may lead to a commensurate decrease in the number of cattle in the United States. The centre seemed to overlook the reality, which is that Australian beef exports to the US—and I know the minister will correct me if I am not right on this—even after the 20-year implementation period, if any of us are still alive to see it, are dependent on a buoyant market in the US. If times are bad over there—that is, if cattle numbers are down or if prices are down, which is the important thing in a market economy—Australia does not get the so-called free access that has been promised, even 20 years from now.

So the environment is left as a poor cousin. The point I want to make is that even the CIE recognised it and the environmental effects statement was about looking at the effect of the implementation of this agreement on the Australian environment as a whole. It was not simply about looking at whether there would be an impact on environmental laws. So the former minister for the environment got that wrong too. I mentioned earlier that a number of North American groups have warned about the environmental impact of this agreement. Those groups are the Center for International Environment Law, the Defenders of Wildlife, Earthjustice, Friends of the Earth, Sierra Club and Pacific Environment. These groups this month have put out a statement that said:

quote.para: The Australia-United States Free Trade Agreement (AUSFTA) threatens to undermine environmental protections both within Australia and the United States. Our organizations representing millions of Americans are therefore opposed to the passage of the AUSFTA in its current form. Our concerns regarding specific areas of the agreement are described below.

speech.para: We have to examine three major areas in the light of the minister's wrong statement that the impact of the agreement as a whole on the environment was not a matter of concern and that Australian laws deal with that. Let us have a look and see. The six North American groups say:

quote.para: The environment chapter of the AUSFTA includes provisions that are generally vague and unenforceable. Moreover, we are troubled by the inclusion of the provisions in Article 19.4 of the agreement, which appear to encourage the Parties to use voluntary measures, as opposed to regulatory instruments, to achieve and maintain high levels of environmental protection. While we believe that voluntary measures can serve a valuable purpose, in most cases they are not an adequate substitute for publicly adopted regulatory standards.

speech.para: The groups possibly do not know of the Howard government's failure to produce environmental laws with teeth in them and its reliance on voluntary measures and the consequent degradation of the environment in Australia on so many fronts, from greenhouse to forest protection to land clearing through to water quality, during its eight years in office. Nevertheless, they go on to say:

quote.para: We also are deeply concerned that the environment chapter does not include a citizen submission process that would allow citizens to address failures by either government to protect the environment. An effective and strong citizen submission process, with clearly enforceable outcomes, should be included in order to ensure that the environment is adequately protected and that the AUSFTA leads to sustainable development rather than to socially and environmentally harmful economic activities.

speech.para: I interpolate again. Here are environment groups calling for the citizens of the country—that is, Australia—to be involved. We have heard no response from the minister about even the requirement for that under the provisions of the free trade agreement and I do not think we are going to hear about it because this government does not want citizens to be involved. This is the executive government of Australia shutting out the Australian people. The six groups go on to talk about investor rights. The agreement, they say:

quote.para: ... does not include an `investor suit' mechanism that permits foreign investors to directly challenge environmental laws and regulations before international tribunals. We welcome the exclusion of such a mechanism. However, the AUSFTA still explicitly leaves the door open to direct suits by multinational investors before ad-hoc international tribunals. Article 11.16.1 of the agreement permits the executives of the two governments to establish an ad-hoc investor suit process in particular cases, without any approval or oversight by either the U.S. Congress or the Australian parliament. By allowing foreign investors to bypass domestic legal processes, investment suits permitted under this procedure would undermine democratic governance concerning public interest policies.

speech.para: This is very serious stuff. I will bet the minister is not going to get up and countermand that except by another series of bland, meaningless, unsubstantiated and vague blandishments. The groups then go on, under investor rights, to say:

quote.para: Moreover, we continue to have significant concerns about the substantive rights provided to foreign investors in the AUSFTA. The agreement provides multinational businesses rights that are similar to those in NAFTA and other agreements. Under NAFTA, both Mexico and Canada have already lost cases involving environmental protections, and the United States faces challenges to public health and environmental standards. These cases have included challenges to policies concerning toxic gasoline additives, hazardous waste treatment, transboundary transport of hazardous waste, open-pit mining mitigation measures, and others.

speech.para: We have the minister here saying that water and land—these vague things that are out there—are looked after by environmental law. This is not so. Here is the experience of people who live under NAFTA who say the multinational corporations will move in under provisions such as in this US-Australia free trade agreement. The corporations can go through international tribunals and can subvert the laws of countries like Canada and Mexico and indeed the United States itself when it comes to the environment, let alone social justice and democratic governance. The groups go on to say:

quote.para: We believe that the rights in these agreements are too broad and grant privileges to multinational investors that go significantly beyond the rights provided under either Australian or U.S. domestic law. The result is that environmental laws and regulations that affect foreign investors will be inappropriately subject to challenge. For example, the AUSFTA includes language requiring that foreign investors be compensated if laws or regulations `indirectly expropriate' their investment interests. The agreement lacks adequate limitations on this provision, making it contrary to long-standing legal principles in Australian and U.S. law that have permitted environmental regulation concerning land use and other policies without a legal requirement to pay compensation.

speech.para: If the multinational corporation does not like environmental law protecting the Australian commons, it can go through the promissory system of the two governments involved, it can go to an international tribunal somewhere on the other side of the planet and Australia can be overruled just as Canada was overruled on gasoline additives that were harmful to public health in that country which they wanted to keep out. Not so; the NAFTA broke that down. Mexico was overruled and the US is now facing being overruled in its environmental laws. The companies get not only over the border but also under the law. The group goes on to talk about their concerns about trade in services:

quote.para: Finally, we are also deeply concerned by the provisions in the 'trade in services' chapter of the ... These rules could impinge on the ability of state, local and federal governments to adopt and enforce environmental standards in environmentally sensitive sectors that are classified as 'services' in trade law—including such sectors as oil and gas extraction, transport and storage operations; mining activities; tourism and hotel construction; water supply; forestry activities; and others.

For these sectors, the ... goes beyond World Trade Organization rules by requiring that governments must endeavor to ensure that domestic regulations are not more burdensome than necessary to ensure the quality of the service. In other words, the agreement requires policymakers to choose the regulatory alternative that is least restrictive of service operations, regardless of issues of cost, efficacy, or democratic preference. For example, restrictions on coastal development could be required to be carried out in the manner that is least restrictive of services operations carried out by foreign hotel operators. The... also prohibits the use of a number of kinds of quantitative restrictions on service operations, which could include forbidding environmental restrictions on the number of offshore oil wells, mining operations, hotels, and other service operations.

These services provisions, for example, are troubling in light of the recent, highly controversial efforts by the Australian company BHP Billiton to establish a liquid natural gas (LNG) terminal off the California coast. The services chapter could impede regulatory measures to address the environmental risks posed by the terminals.
For all of the reasons outlined above, we believe the Australia-United States Free Trade Agreement will undermine efforts to protect the environment and should not be approved.

speech.para: What is Minister Hill's response to that? These are very serious charges. They are very cogently argued. The group says that the vague provisions in this legislation—or to put a more nefarious spin on it I say, `the very carefully crafted provisions which do not tightly protect the environment but rather open the door'—will allow huge corporations with huge economies, huge legal backup and huge access to lobby governments to engage in lawsuits which will override Australia's environmental and social amenity. That is the case, that is the reality, that is what has happened under the NAFTA and that is what will happen under this agreement. The minister says, `No, don't worry about the environment, our laws will look after it.' I ask the minister how he answers these charges.

talk.start.para: —I think Senator Brown put six specific arguments. Firstly, he said that the CIE could provide only a best guess of the greenhouse consequences of the free trade agreement. If that is the case, I think it proves my case. That is the problem of trying to attach environmental cost to a framework agreement. You have to estimate the extent to which there will be economic growth, pursuant to this agreement, and you have to distinguish that from the growth that there would otherwise be. You have to try to assess the nature of that growth, the sources of energy and so forth and, in Senator Brown's own words, you come to a best guess. I think that proves the difficulty of environmental assessments on framework agreements and demonstrates why the Australian approach is a better approach. It means that, when action is to be taken that can have significant effects on a matter of national environmental significance, the Commonwealth legislation will be triggered. So far from proving what I said was wrong, I think it rather proves that what I said was right.

speech.para: Senator Brown's second point was to list the number of organisations which he said were opposed to this agreement because of what they saw as detrimental environmental consequences, but what they are really saying is that they are opposed to economic growth. You can argue that any economic growth has environmental consequences. The issue is whether they are consequences you are prepared to accept for some other benefit. Most of us want the benefit of improved living standards with a minimum environmental downside. That is why we on this side of the chamber support sustainable growth. You best achieve sustainable growth through your own domestic regulatory system; you do not achieve it through a free trade agreement of this type.

Senator Brown's third argument was that the agreement has a prejudice in favour of voluntary rather than regulatory enforcement. I have looked at the agreement and I cannot find that assertion. Article 19.3 says:

quote.para: Each Party shall provide remedies for violations of its environmental laws to ensure the effective enforcement of those laws.

speech.para: Article 19.4 says:

quote.para: Each Party shall promote public awareness of its environmental laws ...

speech.para: I would have thought that is something that Senator Brown would applaud rather than condemn. A well-educated public is more likely to contribute to better environmental outcomes rather than a less informed public.

Senator Brown's fourth argument was that there was insufficient opportunity for citizen-initiated action under this agreement. Again, I would argue that it is not through this agreement; rather, it is through domestic laws that that opportunity is given. Certainly the EPBC legislation broke some new ground in relation to citizens initiating action. As a result of some of those citizen-initiated actions prosecutions have been launched and successfully concluded.

The fifth argument he sought to put was that investors are not subject to rules. Investors into Australia are subject to Australia's domestic laws, whether they be environmental, quarantine or whatever. That is not prejudiced under this agreement. And Australian investors into the US will be subject to their laws as well. Provided those laws are genuinely structured for those purposes, they are not prejudiced by this agreement.

Senator Brown's sixth argument was that the trade in services could in some way be utilised to avoid environmental standards. Again, I have looked at the trade and services part of the agreement and I cannot see how in any way that argument can be sustained. I noticed that Senator Brown did not specifically draw our attention to the part of the language that was of concern to him but rather referred to the views of third parties.
So in relation to the six matters that Senator Brown has just raised, I think that each can be answered more than effectively.

talk.start.para: —Is the minister saying that there is no provision and no way under the agreement in which a corporate entity aggrieved by environmental laws could take an action in a court outside Australia?
—There is no way under this agreement that the EPBC Act can be overruled.

—That is a silly response from the minister. The question I put to the minister was this: is there no avenue for a corporate entity to take a dispute about environmental provisions in Australia to an international tribunal or court?

—I guess Senator Brown is really asking whether a government can argue that a law is not a law for genuine environmental protection but rather has a primary purpose otherwise than for that objective. It is possible under free trade agreements to argue these points. But what I said to Senator Brown is that there is no way that a US investor in Australia can avoid the responsibilities that Australians are subject to under the EPBC legislation.
—If there is a dispute about whether an environmental law is genuine, where does that go?

—The advice I am being given is that theoretically a government could take that issue to the dispute settlement procedures. But the point I am making to Senator Brown is that that is not going to occur in relation to Australia's environmental protection, which was clearly set up in Australian law prior to the introduction of this agreement, which clearly was put in place for no purpose other than proper environmental protection and which was in existence at the time at which the United States not only accepted our environmental laws but also, under this agreement, reinforced our obligation to enforce our environmental laws.

—So the point is made. The US government, under an approach by a corporation, can take Australia to the disputes mechanism. The minister has ventured to say that it can be because the corporation does not think that a law that is brought in here is a genuine environmental law—that that is not the real dinkum reason for the law. For example, in comes a carbon tax, let us say. A US corporation that owns a big slice of the Australian fuel refining and/or selling business—or in the coal industry, for that matter—can say, `That is not a genuine environmental law. They are simply going to raise revenue there.' If the US government happens to agree with that, off we go to the disputes mechanism. Australia's laws can be overridden in that way.

speech.para: The minister has explained step by step. You can take him to the water but you cannot make him drink, even though that is what is important here. It is going to be the Australian laws that are going down the stream. We have august US environmental organisations saying that, under NAFTA, both Mexico and Canada have already lost cases involving environmental protections. That is their law. The United States faces challenges to public health and environmental standards. These cases have included challenges to policies concerning toxic gasoline additive. That is famous—Canada defending against toxic additives being put in gasoline. A US corporation takes a suit against Canada; Canada loses; the law is overriden.

The minister is saying that it cannot happen with us. There are the same provisions. He says it will not happen with us. That is what the Clinton administration assured everybody in the United States—that it would not happen there. Likewise the Canadian and Mexican governments. Wrong. It not only could happen; it did happen. Senator Hill is wrong. It not only can happen in Australia; it will happen, because the same provisions pertain here. It is just that the boffins have not thought it out. They cannot foresee where it is going to come from in this complex world, so they think it will not happen. It will happen.

In the future, Australian environmental law will be challenged under this mechanism. And Australia will lose. Judged by whom? Some faceless joint committee appointed by governments or an international tribunal that it is referred to with power over the environmental protection laws of this country. The minister, who did not know much about it at the start of the evening and seems to know even less about it now, says, `No, that won't happen.' But he knows it will, and that is not speculation; that is practice. That is what has happened. It is quite wrong for a minister, particularly a former minister for the environment, to come in here and say that it will not happen in Australia's case. It will happen. It is going to happen, and the environment groups and their lawyers are right—that is practice; that is what has happened.

This is a clear case of derogation of Australia's laws in sovereignty to a free trade agreement signed by the executive outside this parliament with the parliament having no comeback. This parliament is weakened. This parliament is left without defence such as the case of the US corporation against Canadian law. I am not going to convince the minister because he does not want to hear or know about it and has not studied it, but that is the reality of the situation.

talk.start.para: —I will respond very briefly because, in typical fashion, Senator Brown seeks to unnecessarily, unreasonably cause distress to people. He is seemingly arguing that the US could, through this agreement, enforce upon Australians a detrimental public health outcome. That is simply wrong. What is true is that an agreement of this type is designed to try to reduce barriers to trade and investment in an effort to contribute to economic growth, which can bring significant benefits to community and—an argument that Senator Brown has never been prepared to accept—contribute to better environmental outcomes.

speech.para: Economic growth contributes to the options of better environmental choices whereas Senator Brown, in some of the groups he represents, believes the only way to protect the environment is to restrain economic growth. I think that has been fundamentally demonstrated to be false—in fact, it is a greater threat to environmental outcomes. It would be wrong to let him have the last word in the way that he seeks to frighten Australians either in terms of health outcomes or environmental outcomes in this agreement. This agreement will not in any way prejudice Australia's very sound environmental regulatory system or its very sound health system.

talk.start.para: —I want to take the minister back to the idea of the environmental review which the joint committee needs to carry out at its first meeting. At the beginning of this series of questions from Senator Brown, the minister's answer about the environmental review that will be carried out in the environmental assessment of the agreement was that the review carried out by the Centre for International Economics fulfilled that requirement. Senator Brown read out the CIE comment, in which they said it did not fulfil the requirement. I thought I would have a look at the latest Senate committee that has looked into this issue and what the government senators on that committee were saying. I am going to read from the government senators' interim report of the Senate Select Committee on the Free Trade Agreement between Australia and the United States of America of which Senator Brandis, Senator Ferris and Senator Boswell are members. In paragraph 4.115, they say:

quote.para: ... the Joint Committee—

speech.para: this is of course the joint committee that is implementing the US-Australia free trade agreement—

quote.para: will, at its first meeting, consider reviews by each Party of the environmental effects of the Agreement and afford the public an opportunity to provide views on those effects.

speech.para: It is worth remembering the minister said, `This will be fulfilled by the Centre for International Economics.' In their report, government senators on the committee said:

quote.para: The ... Government will be preparing an environmental assessment of the Agreement in the context of an overall analysis of the Agreement.

speech.para: In light of the minister's comments that the government will settle for the report done by the Centre for International Economics and the government senators' report saying that the government will prepare an environmental assessment of the agreement, can he confirm for us which one is the government's position?

talk.start.para: —I am now a little confused as to whether Senator Nettle is talking about environmental assessment of the agreement prior to it coming into effect or the review process under the agreement. I thought when she commenced she was talking about the latter. In terms of the form of assessment that would be put through the latter, I am advised that that has not yet been determined, which is not surprising. In terms of the environmental assessment of the agree-ment itself, I am advised again that it was found that the agreement did not trigger the EPBC legislation. The review that the government took into account was that of the Centre for Independent Economics, to which we have been referring for the last hour or so.

—The Centre for Independent Economics said that there would not be an impact on Australia's environment and that the EPBC would not be affected, yet in that same agreement—and Senator Brown read it out—they also said that that was not the comprehensive environmental analysis that needed to be carried out. The joint committee that implements the US-Australia free trade agreement on which the governments of Australia and the US appoint individuals, at its first meeting, needs to have an environmental assessment of the review before it can proceed. According to the government senators' report, the United States had already prepared their draft review in December last year, which is available on the US Trade Representative's web site. The Senate committee report states that the government:

quote.para: ... will be preparing an environmental assessment of the Agreement in the context of an overall analysis of the Agreement.

speech.para: Is this occurring? What is the time frame?

talk.start.para: —As I said to Senator Nettle, the process leading up to the joint committee's meetings will be determined by the Australian government. Each party is to report on its environmental assessments. Part of the debate in this chamber earlier tonight was over the fact that Australia and the US have different ways of approaching environmental protection. The US puts greater weight on assessments of agreements; we put greater weight on assessments of prospective actions. I argued that our approach is more effective because it is much more specific. That led us into a debate about what was described by Senator Brown as a `best guess' of greenhouse consequences from a framework agreement. I said it demonstrated the difficulty of carrying out an environmental assessment of an agreement when it is impossible to predict with certainty the actions that will be taken thereunder.

—So the Centre for International Economics' cursory look at the environment, which they themselves state is not a comprehensive analysis, is enough for the government. So far we have heard from the minister that the government has no intention of carrying out further environmental reviews. That is despite the comments from the government senators that they will be carrying those out, and it is despite the requirement within appendix B of the agreement that a review of the environmental effects of the agreement shall be carried out `and shall provide the public an opportunity to provide views on those effects'. It is not a very good start for the government, I would have thought, in meeting its own commitments and the commitments under the trade agreement to carry out that environmental analysis.

speech.para: The Centre for Independent Economics' cursory environmental study did not, so far as I am aware, provide any opportunity for the public to provide views on those effects. The government seems to think that is good enough. It is not good enough for the Greens, and we will continue to pursure this. It was a recommendation that came out of the first Senate inquiry that I was a part of. It was a recommendation that came out of the second inquiry, which was supported by the gov-ernment senators on that inquiry. Yet the minister seems to think that the Centre for International Economics' report, which looked at this as part of an overall study, admitting it was not the full environmental analysis, is good enough. It is good enough for the government in terms of looking at the environmental consequences of this agreement.

Over the weekend I was in parts of regional New South Wales talking with orchardists who are concerned about the impact of the quarantine laws in this legislation on their capacity to continue with their crops—their apples, their pears. They are concerned about the trade committees that are set up as part of this agreement to look at our quarantine laws, which have US trade representatives on them and which have explicit criteria to improve investment in trade between the two countries—not to scientifically look after our quarantine standards, as is appropriate, through the WTO.

Those orchardists in New South Wales are concerned about the environmental con-sequences of the US-Australia free trade agreement. The minister says to us here today that the Centre for International Economics has had a cursory look at it and admitted it is not good enough, but it is good enough for the government. It is not very comforting for those people whose livelihoods rely on quarantine laws and the environmental protections that are a part of this agreement. This agreement sets out a framework under which they can be undermined, and the government say, `Before the agreement comes into effect, we're not even going to look at the environmental consequences that impact on your livelihoods as orchardists in parts of New South Wales.' It is not good enough.

talk.start.para: —I want to say a few words about this particular issue. I found quite interesting the minister's response to the question of an environmental assessment that Australia may have taken the stronger or preferred approach compared to the United States. I want to ask the minister whether or not he agrees that, under US trade laws, there is a requirement to produce a report on the environment and that in the interim report—as far as I am aware, going back some four months—one of the things the United States wanted to look at as part of the negotiations was the commitment by Australia to the effective enforcement of its environmental laws. If that is an expectation that the Americans had of Australia, if nothing else, it implies to me that there is an obligation on our government to ensure that the tender documents—at least as they were dealt with at the time—are written in such a way as to analyse the economic, social and cultural impacts as well as the environment.

speech.para: Firstly, I want to ask whether or not the minister agrees with that sort of reciprocal obligation, if you like, given that the United States were the ones who insisted upon that as part of the interim report. Secondly, in relation to the work done by the CIE and the first report that provided the basis for the APEC Study Centre report that was commissioned by DFAT, was this environmental impact assessment also part of any documents or instructions that may have assisted the APEC Study Centre or at least the CIE? I know that way back in early March the minister responded to a question by saying that there was a restricted tender process. I am not sure whether we have seen the terms of reference for the restricted tender process—although, thankfully, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade did eventually provide information to the select committee, I seem to recall, on others that did tender at the time.

At the time the APEC Study Centre were commissioned by DFAT were there any specific instructions given to look at the environment and particularly social and cultural impacts? I think this does come down to looking at the bottom line overall about whether or not it is in the national interest. If that was not done, why wasn't it done in that case, particularly given that this was something that the United States had insisted upon, not just as a result of trade laws but also implying that they took it fairly seriously? Didn't it also mean that Australia should have taken it as seriously as they did and made sure that those who drove this behind the scenes—whether in Minister Vaile's office, in DFAT or elsewhere; all of the consultants engaged—were at least looking at the other bottom line issues and not just at the economic outcome? Whilst the government may talk about the benefits, I think a weak part of the analysis is that we do not have a proper assessment of the cost, and that cost also has to include the environmental, the social and the cultural impacts.

Does the government agree with what the US was seeking as part of an appropriate commitment by Australia regarding the effective enforcement of its environmental laws—not just looking at retaining the right to regulate in our national interest as far as the environment is concerned but also undertaking that analysis? Surely, that is clearly what was meant by the interim report that was provided by the US trade representative. It clearly indicated that, whilst they were doing it, there was an expectation that we would do likewise. I wonder whether the minister might be able to answer those questions, particularly in terms of whether or not instructions were given or there were discussions that assessments would be done so that we knew not only what the benefits were going to be but what the costs were going to be.

We still do not have answers in any of the reports about the costs on a range of different issues. We presume the free trade agreement may well end up being of net benefit, but the reality is that there are so many aspects of it that have been deficient or neglected completely that we do not have, as far as a ledger is concerned, an assessment of what the bottom line cost is going to be in order to make some fair assessment on whether it is a fair agreement and certainly in Australia's interests. As I said earlier to the minister, it is not just a question of dealing with the environmental issues in that narrow perspective; it is also a question of looking at the impact upon our quarantine laws, food labelling laws and so on. Quite frankly, there has been very little assessment of that in terms of what the cost is going to be. This does need an answer because this is probably one of the most important things that this parliament will deal with this year—and is certainly one of the most important things in my time in parliament. I think the parliament and certainly the Australian people deserve sufficient explanation from the government about what the costs are going to be, because we have not heard that at all. All we keep hearing about is the net benefit. We have not looked at the ledger, because there has been no ledger drawn up—because the government has failed to do the analysis of what the costs are going to be.

This question has been raised time and time again over the past four months. It was recommended by the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties—the government's own creation—which was supposed to be a mechanism to guarantee that these issues were dealt with. It is not enough just to talk about recommending that all future free trade agreements be assessed on that bottom line. I ask the minister to respond to those issues because we still do not have details about the specific costs and whether or not this free trade agreement really is in the national interest—beyond just the trumpeting of the rhetoric about a net benefit. It simply is just not there.

talk.start.para: —The fact that the United States were interested to ensure that the other party had sufficiently demanding environmental laws I think is a good thing. Obviously, in this instance the United States were satisfied that the Australian environmental standards were demanding and they were clearly prepared to enter into an agreement on that basis. So, yes, they will conduct their assessments under their laws—or practices—which as I understand it include doing an assessment on an agreement. We on our part will principally focus on the actions that might be taken within the framework agreement rather than try to assess the consequences of the agreement itself. I argued earlier tonight that I think the way in which we do it actually gives greater confidence in terms of protecting environmental values.

speech.para: If the United States had been negotiating with a country that had not developed a sophisticated environmental protection framework, I guess, through the negotiating process, it might have sought some assurances in that regard. But, obviously, that did not apply to Australia. Basically, the responsibility for us to protect our environment remains with us. I will repeat what I said earlier, but I think it is also relevant to what Senator Ridgeway is arguing. Article 19.2 of the agreement states:

quote.para: The Parties recognise that it is inappropriate to encourage trade or investment by weakening or reducing the protections afforded in their respective environmental laws.

speech.para: So, firstly, we ensure that each other's environmental laws are adequate and, secondly, we reinforce that those laws should not be weakened for the objective of trade benefit.

It is true that we seek triple bottom line outcomes. We want better environmental outcomes, we want better social outcomes and we want better economic outcomes. We believe that such objectives can be achieved. This agreement helps on the economic side by opening up new markets to us, and we will protect our environmental bottom line through our own legislation, regulation and practices. In terms of social outcomes, we will similarly do our best to ensure that domestically there is an equitable distribution of the wealth that we hope will be facilitated through this agreement. They are not either/or propositions.

Costs are part of the debate we have been having since half past seven tonight, and I have argued that an attempt to judge the environmental costs simply on the basis of the framework agreement is likely to make you little the wiser. It will not tell you, for example, whether agriculture is going to be produced on a sustainable basis or not. It will not tell you about the choice of energy sources. These are matters that we will determine domestically in order that, as I said, we can not only achieve economic benefits but also protect our environmental heritage and seek the social outcomes that certainly this side of the chamber is committed to.

talk.start.para: —It is a pretty specious argument, Chair, isn't it? The government comes up with its statements about how this is going to be a great economic winner for Australia. The same arguments apply. The government does not know whether there are going to be Democrat administrations, Republican administrations or Green administrations in the US for the next 20 or 100 years. It has no idea. It does not know whether there is going to be World War III, a SARS outbreak or who knows what—or a World Trade Organisation or global compact which could supersede this agreement. It certainly does not know about, for example—and has not written into those cost estimates—global warming, which is something the government can do something about but does not. Yet it comes up with these multibillion-dollar assessments about the agreement being a winner for Australia as well as the US. Give me the calculations, please, and the hard, ironclad assumptions on which they are based, Minister. And you cannot.

speech.para: But it is so important to get an economic assessment out there and to beguile people with, `We think it's going to be worth this many billion extra in trade, and we think it's going to be worth this many extra hundred million to Australia's GDP 20 years from now'—and they have no idea. But they make their best effort at it. When it comes to the environment, it is a different story. It is difficult. All sorts of assumptions have to be made, but they do not do it because the environment is not worth it. The environment does not rate under this government. The assessment of the environment is too hard. It would require too much of an effort; it would require too many presumptions to be put in. You can do it for the holy dollar, but you cannot do it for our holy environment. That is the difference. This government is besotted with money and not a little greed, but the other values do not count.

We in the Greens think differently. We think that there is an environmental assessment required. I did not say, as the minister wants to put it, that the CIE was wanting to best-guess the extra production of greenhouse gases under provisions of this legislation when you looked at the beef industry; that is what the CIE says. It is a best guess. So are all the economic assessments—they are best guesses. The minister is very clever at this, Chair—I do not know whether you have noticed. He wants to confuse the issue by taking it off on a different tangent, but he should not get away with it.

We are not arguing—and the CIE is not arguing—that an environmental impact assessment is required by the laws of the country, that the EPBC Act is the prime environmental law in this country and that, on the surface of it, it is not affected. No, we are arguing that you can do an environmental impact assessment; CIE says so and gives examples, but says it has not done a definitive assessment. If the government does not come up with a definitive effects statement with provision for public input, it is breaking the first instruction to the secret, unappointed joint committee that will arbitrate on these matters: the six faceless men—and I am sure they all will be if they are appointed by the honourable Prime Minister, Mr Howard.

The minister says that the effects statement is not about the effects on the environment; yet the experts—the Centre for International Economics—say it is. Because it is convenient for him tonight and he finds that it is troublesome ground, he is going to put his head in the sand, hope everybody else does as well and say, `Oh, no, that's not what it's about.' He has a smart alec strategy to divert people by saying: `Oh, well, that was it. There's no requirement for a national environmental effects statement on the impact of the free trade agreement on this great country of ours called Australia.' Well, it will not wash. There is a requirement, and there should be public response to that.

Annex 1 of the free trade agreement is about values other than quick dollars; it is about the environment. But the minister says: `We won't worry about that one. It doesn't mean what it says. There is a provision written into the free trade agreement, but it's not going to matter. Don't you worry about it. I've reinterpreted it tonight on my feet. It doesn't matter.' That is because it is a value issue; it is about the environment. Social justice issues will be treated in the same way, as we will find out in the next day or two as we debate this matter. Democracy will be treated the same way, as will Australia's ability to write laws for the benefit of the global commons that cannot be superseded by an agreement like this which is all about dollars—in particular, dollars for the already rich and powerful. That is what this agreement is about.

It is pretty shameful that a former minister for the environment, despite his record, cannot get up here tonight and say: `We are always genuinely concerned for the Australian environment. There is a provision in the agreement which says that each party shall provide a review of environmental effects for the first joint committee's consideration. That environmental effects review will be done seriously for the national interest and, indeed, with public input—during, not after its effects have been discovered.'

But this government—even despite the Prime Minister's concern that the environment will be on the agenda at the election—is, with the opposition, pushing through a free trade agreement that does not respect the environment. Therefore, I ask the spokesperson for the opposition, Senator Conroy: what is the opposition's interpretation of the requirement for a review of the environmental effects of this agreement that `shall provide the public an opportunity to provide views on those effects'? If the opposition wins government in the next month or two before the free trade agreement is finalised and implemented on 1 January, will the opposition see that there is an environmental effects statement, into which the public has input, on the full ramifications of the free trade agreement?

talk.start.para: —Not me.

—Senator Conroy on behalf of the Latham opposition says, `Not me.' I do not want to misrepresent him, so I will make sure I sit down with plenty of time for Senator Conroy to answer the question: will the opposition ensure there is an environmental effects statement? Will it make sure that the public has input? Will it do the assessment on this extraordinarily important component—the impact of the free trade agreement on the national environment—if the government will not?

—I can understand Senator Brown's frustration at the process. The Labor Party has said consistently that the process involved in this free trade agreement has been unsatisfactory. There has not been enough consultation and public discussion on this. I can understand Senator Brown's frustration, because Senator Brown and Senator Nettle tried to get onto the Senate Select Committee on the Free Trade Agreement between Australia and the United States of America so they could participate in the discussions. But, in what can only be described as a very despicable act, the Democrats voted with the government to knock the Greens off the committee. speech.para: As you would know, Senator Brown, the Labor Party voted for you. It is probably one of the few times in my life that I would ever vote for you or Senator Nettle, but we voted for the Greens to be represented on the committee. So I understand your frustration at you and Senator Nettle not getting an opportunity to be part of this debate. I can only suggest that you have a look behind you at who tried to ensure that you did not get a voice and an opportunity to participate. I would have welcomed your participation in the limited process that was available to the Senate. Labor welcomed your support of the Senate select committee, which the government was initially very reluctant to support.

The Labor Party has consistently stated its concerns about this process, and it has consistently written reports. Senator Cook recently wrote a Senate committee report on the failings of the current system, and he made a whole string of recommendations. Many of those were picked up in the ALP national platform. Labor has said that, in the future, it would support environmental impact statements beforehand and much more public consultation. When the Labor Party are in government, we will go down that path, because we do agree with Senator Brown that these are important issues. As to whether we are prepared to stop this process coming into force, I suspect not. Unfortunately this government has controlled the process. talk.start.para: —There is no excuse in that. The Labor Party is putting itself forward as the alternative government within just a month or two, and this agreement will be implemented under its vote in that period. Therefore, if Labor were elected, it would come in with all the opportunities that the government has had. The requirement for a review of the environmental effects is not coming from the floor of the chamber—which has been sidelined by this process—but from the free trade agreement itself.
